column1: Menomonie () is a city in and the county seat of Dunn County in the western part of the U.S. state of Wisconsin. The city's population was 16
Named for the original inhabitants of the area
column3: the city forms the core of the United States Census Bureau's Menomonie Micropolitan Statistical Area (MSA)
column4: which includes all of Dunn County (2010 population: 43
column5: 857). The Menomonie MSA and the Eau Claire–Chippewa Falls metropolitan area to the east form the Census Bureau's Eau Claire-Menomonie Consolidated Metropolitan Statistical Area.

column1: The earliest known residents of the area were people from the Trempealeau Hopewell Culture of the Middle Woodland Period (1400 AD). Evidence from their culture includes a mound from the Wakanda Mounds Group in Wakanda Park
column2: along the western shore of Lake Menomin. Most of these mounds are thought to be from Effigy Mound cultures from this time period. Artifacts from the Late Woodland Period (400-1000 AD) have also been uncovered. It is theorized that agricultural villages supported the population during summer months
column3: transitioning to hunting and gathering from fall through spring. The next known population group is the Santee Dakota in the 1600s and 1700s

It is important to remember that a large percentage of the 42% between 18 and 24 were students at the University of Wisconsin-Stout.

column1: Menomonie Municipal Airport (KLUM) serves the city and surrounding communities.
Menomonie is served by Menomonie High School.

St. Paul's Lutheran School is a Christian Pre-K-8 school of the Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod (WELS) in Menomonie.The city is the home of the University of Wisconsin–Stout and a campus of Chippewa Valley Technical College.
Dunn County Jail is located on the eastern edge of Menomonie. It houses sentenced and non-sentenced
